body: Shouldn't you be reading from stdout _before_ calling `recv_exit_status()`?

Hmm, that does indeed seem to be the case, once I move the recv_exit_status after reading from stdout/stderr, then I can execute larger commands.

Seems this could be handled in a more informative way other than hanging indefinitely though. Especially as this error may be non-obvious as it works at smaller output sizes and nothing enforces this ordering.

As an added detail, I used this ordering based on the logic that since recv_exit_status blocked until a command was complete according to the docs, it would guarantee that the command was complete and we had the full output before reading. I was not sure that just calling read without that would really ensure you had all the output. But clearly I do not have a clear picture of how this is all working.

Can you try a modern Paramiko (1.7.7+, ideally 1.10+)? 1.7.5 is ancient (& unsupported) at this point and is missing oodles of fixes, some of which might apply to this situation.

I'd also check out how Fabric handles this (or just use Fabric itself if your needs aren't super unique) as it's the current best implementation example. E.g.: https://github.com/fabric/fabric/blob/bf216865b5c835b8e19c1cb6e23b72166ae47edd/fabric/operations.py#L793-L837

Please comment if you are still having the issue after trying those things, and we may reopen. Thanks!
Sure thing. Upgraded to 1.15.1 and re-ran test script included above. Confirmed that this does _not_ reproduce on more recent versions. Sorry for the noise.

issue.title: fix(controller): read from SSH channel before checking exit status

repository.name: deis
repository.description: Deis v1, the CoreOS and Docker PaaS: Your PaaS. Your Rules.

issue.body:
Controller code was checking the SSH channel's exit status _before_ reading data from it, which surprisingly worked--up to a certain size in the neighborhood of [2182300 bytes](https://github.com/deis/deis/issues/3035#issuecomment-73433740). The similar issue paramiko/paramiko#448 suggested calling `recv_exit_status()` first was the problem, and changing the call order does fix large file output from `deis run` for the largest test files I've used, which previously failed.

``` console
$ deis run -- "cat pg3008.txt | wc -c"
Running `cat pg3008.txt | wc -c`...
2474769
$ deis run -- "cat pg3008.txt"
Running `cat pg3008.txt`...
...
15331. jarg422h.htm#The%20Cuckoo's%20Egg
15332. jarg422h.htm#wizard
15333. jarg422h.htm#wannabee




End of The Project Gutenberg Etext of The New Hacker's Dictionary version
4.2.2

$
```

Closes #3035.

body:
For the record, I ran into this same issue while running Paramiko 1.15.4. For a large enough output, `recv_exit_status()` hangs. The fix was the same: call `stdout.channel.recv_exit_status()` _after_ calling `read()` on each of the output streams, instead of before.

I found this confusing for the same reason that @kprantis did. The [doc for `recv_exit_status()`](http://docs.paramiko.org/en/1.15/api/channel.html#paramiko.channel.Channel.recv_exit_status) makes it sound like it's safe to call first since it waits until everything is done.

> If the command hasnâ€™t finished yet, this method will wait until it does, or until the channel is closed. If no exit status is provided by the server, -1 is returned.

@bitprophet - Does it make sense to add a warning somewhere in the documentation about how large output can cause hangs if `read()` and `recv_exit_status()` are not called in the correct order? Or is there perhaps a bug in the behavior of  `recv_exit_status()`?

I can work on a concise reproduction of the issue if it'll help you address this.

Here's a concise reproduction of the issue:

``` python
import sys
import paramiko

print(sys.version)
print(paramiko.__version__)

client = paramiko.client.SSHClient()
client.load_system_host_keys()
client.set_missing_host_key_policy(paramiko.client.AutoAddPolicy())

client.connect(hostname='127.0.0.1')
output_len = 2097150

while True:
    stdin, stdout, stderr = client.exec_command(
        'printf %{}s'.format(output_len),
        get_pty=True)

    exit_status = stdout.channel.recv_exit_status()
    stdout_output = stdout.read().decode('utf8').rstrip('\n')

    print(len(stdout_output))
    output_len += 1
```

On my system, the output I get is:

```
$ python3 paramiko-large-output-hang.py 
3.5.0 (default, Sep 23 2015, 04:42:00) 
[GCC 4.2.1 Compatible Apple LLVM 7.0.0 (clang-700.0.72)]
1.16.0
2097150
2097151
2097152
- hang -
```

So the largest output Paramiko can handle when `recv_exit_status()` is called first is 2097152 bytes, which is exactly 2 MiB. Any larger than that and it hangs. If I move `recv_exit_status()` to after the `read()`, Paramiko sails past that limit without issue.

Searching the codebase for 2097152, I found [this result](https://github.com/paramiko/paramiko/blob/2a99a8c9a4bde66720e9357963ce1896830528a1/paramiko/transport.py#L271-L273), though I wouldn't know if it explains this behavior.

I don't have time to dig further into this, but I can add the warning to `recv_exit_status()`'s documentation if that sounds good to you @bitprophet.

Transport window size could definitely have something to do with it, tho I'm rusty on the details (the joys of inheriting code you didn't write).

Doesn't really change the overall equation, though - until someone has time to seriously dig and determine whether the old documentation was 100% incorrect or if we've introduced a bug somewhere, the best time/efficacy tradeoff is just to amend said docs.

Since I'm looking at this (& am persnickety about language) I'll go write the warning myself now. thanks @nchammas !
Sounds good to me. Thanks for maintaining Paramiko, @bitprophet.

Actually, I can confirm/deny the relationship to that window size variable by supplying a larger/smaller value to `myclient.get_transport().default_window_size` (as of 1.15 and up). Setting it much smaller makes the hang much sooner, setting it much larger, conversely likewise.

I still don't know enough about the details to know _why_ this is happening but it makes me lean more towards "actual bug". But I've got other work I gotta do so still gonna slap the warning on here for now =/

Can you please have a look at this paramiko question?
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/34351455/paramiko-rtnetlink-answers-no-such-file-or-directory
These don't look like a paramiko problem at all. This page is about a specific issue and that issue has been addressed (though somewhat disappointingly). Please do not spam with unrelated demands.
